overview: Overview of the legal system in Australia:
The concept of property and ownership in Australia
The general law and the Torrens land registration systems
The legal nature of land: improvements, fixtures and chattels
Co-ownership: subdivision, joint tenancy in common
intended learning outcomes: Adopt an ethical viewpoint to real property matters;
Understand the processes of law in the context of real property;
Use effective written communications in a professional report;
Use effective oral communications in debating legal principles.

additional pre-requisite: Admission into or selection of one of the following:
MC-DINFENG Master of Digital Infrastructure Engineering

assessments.description: Assignment two, due towards the end of semester. 1000 words
assessments.timing: Second half of the teaching period

assessments.description: One written examination, not exceeding three hours. 3 hours. Hurdle requirement:. A grade of at least 40% must be achieved in the final examination in order to pass the subject.

Semester 1.Contact hours: one 2-hour lecture, and one 1-hour tutorial per week

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.

Related Handbook entries: This subject contributes to the following:

About the Community Access Program (CAP): This subject is available through theCommunity Access Program(also called Single Subject Studies) which allows you to enrol in single subjects offered by the University of Melbourne, without the commitment required to complete a whole degree.
Entry requirements including prerequisites may apply. Please refer to theCAP applications pagefor further information.

Available to Study Abroad and/or Study E: This subject is available to students studying at the University from eligible overseas institutions on exchange and study abroad. Students are required to satisfy any listed requirements, such as pre- and co-requisites, for enrolment in the subject.
